p.s: The editorial Language learning in the UK: can't, won't, don't by John Worne which was published 27 January 2015 in The Telegraph concerns the topic of learning international languages in the UK, more specifically the decreasing number of students who study foreign languages.
Worne introduces his aritcle by stating that people in the UK do not see the need to learn any languages other than English.
As studysstudies show, the number of students studying English is steadily declining, even though primary school as well as universities now offer other languages.
Worne presents arguments of those who oppose their view, for example that everyone in the world of business speaks English or that you can use your phone for translations.
They say that it is important to learn foreign languages for a number of things, including trade, diplomacy and national security.
Especially in the job market there's more demand for qualified people with foreign language skills then for those without.

In Worne's opinion there is a need to change the British people's attitude towards learning other languages which can be achieved through a cultural shift in the parental influence as well as through the school and education system.
